awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of Thorny Flat Next Generation Cluster for High-Performance Computing in West Virginia
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will enable West Virginia University (WVU), the flagship Land Grant University for the state of West Virginia (WV) with over 31,000 students, to acquire a High Performance Computing (HPC) cluster called Thorny Flat.  The project will use the resource to support a broad spectrum of research efforts from cosmology to neuroscience, as well as expand utilization of the resource to non-traditional disciplines like systems ecology and biometrics.  In addition, an important goal of the project is to nurture a cohort of new HPC users across West Virginia, a region in acute need of economic diversification. Moreover, the project plans to use the HPC cluster to establish collaborations that will serve to expand and transition the WV economy toward a focus on the high-level technology sector, a critical need in this disadvantaged region.

Specifically, the new HPC cluster will accelerate research projects in biophysical chemistry studies with implications for drug delivery and diagnostic imaging; state-of-the-art code development for materials optimization; and simulations of binary neutron star mergers for future LIGO gravity wave observations.  As well, the resource will catalyze new efforts in Appalachian watershed dynamics, business analytics, and the university's burgeoning quantitative neuroscience program, with six new hires planned for 2017.  With established Centers of Research Excellence in gravitational wave astronomy, STEM education, water security, regional health disparities, and responsible natural gas utilization, the university is devoting new resources to leverage existing strengths in neuroscience and cybersecurity. The availability of high quality infrastructure, such as Thorny Flat, will be essential to the success of many of these computationally intense efforts, led by 35 faculty in conjunction with 180 postdocs, graduate students, and undergrads.

Moreover, the project is committed to using the HPC cluster for training and support for both the university and state-wide research communities.  For example, courses from a diverse set of disciplines will utilize the cluster as a vital training resource, and the project plans to integrate with an annual week-long HPC Summer Institute providing hands-on training to users from across the state.  Furthermore, the project will broaden demand for HPC resources from less traditionally computational areas to address critical big data issues in water security, opiate addiction, and health care disparities. In parallel, the project will be cultivating the next generation of HPC coders and diversifying the pool with 7 female faculty mentors.  In addition, the expanded infrastructure and development of a well-qualified HPC workforce will promote additional university partnerships with regional federal labs, as well as with regional industrial partners.

por.por_cntn:
The Thorny Flat project was a significant upgrade to West Virginia University?s (WVU) existing high performance computing (HPC) capabilities, providing increased capacity and measurably faster graphics processing unit (GPU) accelerators for a wide variety of applications ranging from drug discovery to business data logistics to high-throughput screening of new materials for use in chemical applications. The project also served as WVU?s initial effort to establish regional relationships with other HPC centers, as it was co-located at the Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center (PSC). Our initial investment in working with PSC eventually led to a second co-location relationship that was established between Carnegie Mellon University and PSC, demonstrating that PSC could serve as an HPC hub for institutions of higher learning in Appalachia. The project also serves as the central HPC resource for the university that allowed us to pursue funding for a special purpose GPU machine that was awarded in Fall 2021.

The Thorny Flat project established HPC computing as a truly centralized shared resource for researchers at WVU and throughout the state of West Virginia, providing the opportunity for >30 faculty members to invest in the cluster as well as investments from the department of chemistry and the college of Business and Economics. It will benefit current and future computational research in a wide array of areas: development of targeted diagnostic imaging agents, drug development for treatment of neurodegenerative disorders, design of catalysts used in production of chemical feedstocks, optimization of combustion processes for enhanced efficiency of power plant turbines, fast processing of big data sets from the Green Bank radio telescope and other interstellar communications, development of optimized logistics flows for business management, next-generation sequencing of biological samples, development of detailed water maps of the watershed for the entire state of West Virginia, screening of metabolites for drug discovery through the use of arrays of enzymes tethered to polymer substrates, and developing visual recognition algorithms for applications in forensics, to name a few.

 

The project has enabled this research because it was able to accommodate the increase in our user base and the inherent need to develop and apply approaches that can utilize nodes with a higher core count and GPU accelerators that are capable of working with big data sets compared to WVU?s previous-generation cluster. The Internet2 connection between PSC and WVU ensures that data transfers and communication between the two endpoints is seamless; coupled with the extensive track record of PSC in hosting cutting-edge cluster technologies such as Bridges-1, Bridges-2, Neocortex, and Anton2, the Thorny Flat project allowed WVU researchers to rapidly expand the scope of their computational research and provided opportunities for collaboration with the extensive network of researchers associated with PSC with expertise in machine learning and artificial intelligence.

Improving the capacity and capability of computational researchers at WVU brings broader impacts to West Virginia and the greater Appalachia region. This capacity has led to recruitment of faculty and student participants from West Virginia State University, a historically black college, as well as from Fairmont State University, West Liberty University, Potomac State College, and Marshall University. In addition, the Thorny Flat project will play a critical role in providing training opportunities for undergraduate students in the newly-established Data Science program at WVU, as well as establishment of dedicated course offerings in the areas of physics, chemistry, geology information systems, business data analytics, and scientific programming.
